attributes.action: Change the zero carbon emission goals to 2025 instead of 2050
attributes.background: By 2050, If we keep producing this amount of carbon emissions, It will be too late to act. The UN recently released a article, In which, speakers warn that there are only 11 years left to prevent irreversible damage. 2050 is too late. We must act now!
attributes.additional_details:
It is possible to achieve our climate goals earlier if the Government take action.
In 2050 I will be in my 40s. I want a better future for me and for generations on. I and many others will have to live through the consequences of climate change in the UK, like so many already are in other countries.
 
The UN article: https://www.un.org/press/en/2019/ga12131.doc.htm

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban UK imports of soy not certified as being grown sustainably
attributes.background: The growing of soy beans in environmentally sensitive regions (e.g. the Amazon Rainforest) is helping to fuel deforestation and climate change.
attributes.additional_details:
Much of these soy products are exported to the UK for animal feeds, and some for direct human consumption, where alternatives products are available
The UK government has a responsibility to reduce environmental impacts. This includes indirect impact via consumption.
 
Much soy in the UK is used for animal feed (~75% by weight), so its environmental damage is not seen by the consumer. The UK government needs to ban imports of soy where it cannot be certified that its production is not negatively impacting the environment, pushing our production markets to use more environmentally friendly sources of soy or alternatives products altogether.

departments.name: Department for International Trade

attributes.action: Introduce a ban on sales of new petrol and diesel cars by 2025 in the UK
attributes.background: Both Norway and the Netherlands have voted to ban the sales of new petrol and diesel cars by 2025 and 2030 respectively. It will be impossible to hit global carbon reduction targets without radical actions, such as this. The UK should be leading the way on reducing the impact of Climate Change.
attributes.additional_details: The UK has committed to being Carbon Neutral by 2050, to achieve this we will need to rapidly reduce CO2 emissions with 33% coming from transport. Bringing in the ban of new petrol and diesel vehicles will accelerate the transition to low carbon transport which itself will improve air quality.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Introduce a Climate Change subject to the National School Curriculum
attributes.background:
To add a core subject that will educate school children and young people on
What climate change is.
What change is happening on a local, national and global level.
What to expect in the short, medium and long-term.
Strategies and practical skills to cope with the challenges they will face.
attributes.additional_details: The world climate is changing rapidly and ecosystems are collapsing. It will impact every aspect of life. The generations in school will respond to the impact of climate change. They will run our hospitals, plan food and water distribution and manage huge social and economic change. It is practical to prepare them. It will give them agency to impact their future, prepare them to meet unprecedented challenges and put the UK in a stronger position to cope with the biggest test we will ever face.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Ban plastic bags in the UK
attributes.background: Single use plastic bags are problematic, taking up to 1000 years to biodegrade; even then they still exist as micro plastics. We need the government to ban plastic bags in order to try and help the current climate change issue to which these plastic bags are contributing majorly to.
attributes.additional_details: We need to act now, before it’s too late. Plastic bags hinder the quality of our earth, despite it only being the start. We as the UK, need to start being more responsible for our actions on how we’re damaging our earth. Although you might think this won’t change anything, it’s a start. A start to make our world a better, environmentally friendly world. Please share this to everyone you can so we can try and out a stop to climate change once and for all. Thank you

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Run a Public Awareness Campaign about the Climate and Ecological Emergency
attributes.background: We need the government to run a ‘Climate and Ecological Awareness’ public information campaign that will reach as wide an audience as possible.  The government has carried out such campaigns in the past for issues that posed far less danger to our well-being, for example the anti-smoking campaign.
attributes.additional_details:
The UK Committee on Climate Change is telling us that we are not currently on track for our 2050 net-zero target and we are likely to see global warming of 2-4 degrees by the end of this century. This is far higher than the levels deemed ‘safe’ in the IPCC special report of 2018.   Many of us are oblivious to the damage that we wreak daily on our environment by our activities.

We all need to get involved in facing the challenge, so that the UK can be a role-model for the rest of the world.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Protect Bumblebees and support increased bumblebee numbers
attributes.background: Help to save the diminishing habitats of bees from development and climate change by making bumblebees a protected species under UK law, banning harmful pesticides that kill bees, and providing funding to boost bee numbers across the country.
attributes.additional_details:
As one of the greatest pollinators, bees are essential in keeping the environment healthy and play a vital role in securing stable food supply. 

Without bees, millions of plants could die and the UK could fall further from meeting its environmental targets.

Action must be taken now to save this magnificent species from potential extinction on UK soil.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Revise guidance to allow Civil Weddings with 6 guests during all lockdowns
attributes.background: The Government should change the guidance on Civil Wedding ceremonies to allow them during the current pandemic regardless of tier or national lockdown restrictions. We ask that a maximum of 6 guests to be able to attend if the venue space allows to maintain social distance.
attributes.additional_details: Love conquers all. Love offers hope and faith which is desperately needed in these times. It is a human right to be able to form an official married bond, and this should never be stripped away from us as it currently has been. We never know when this world will take us (especially in this current climate), so it is not just to allow only deathbed weddings. Marriage progresses lives, and the economy through buying a home/car, having children, fees of document changes, loans etc. We need to marry

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Set stricter legal targets for air quality and increase funding for research
attributes.background: The Government’s planned new legal targets for air quality must align with the WHO air quality guideline levels. It should also increase funding for research and development to develop cleaner energy sources and reduce plastic air pollution from tyres. This will also help combat climate change.
attributes.additional_details:
Each year at least 28,000 people in the UK die prematurely because of air pollution, including children. Air pollution has been linked to heart disease, lung disease and cancer, and can exacerbate allergies, skin conditions and pregnancy complications. 
 
Currently we are above the World Health Organisation guideline levels for multiple pollutants. Data from the World Bank shows that 66% of the UK population were exposed to pollution above the WHO standards in 2017.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Extend the Green Homes Grant Scheme for Heating and Insulation
attributes.background: This scheme was introduced to boost the post-COVID economy and combat climate change but it only runs for a limited period (currently till March 2022), severely limiting who benefits.
attributes.additional_details:
We call on the government to extend the Green Homes scheme for 5 years or until 90% of homes have low carbon heating. 

Heating and hot water account for 20% of UK greenhouse gas emissions. 
Low carbon heating and home insulation can minimise this, but are too expensive for many people. 

At current installation rates it will take 700 years to reach every UK home. Demand for these grants has already outstripped installer capacity, but potential new installers are finding it difficult to justify training costs for returns in the short scheme timeframe. 

This scheme must be extended to grow jobs and help the climate.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Treat Carbon emissions as Hazardous Waste in planning process
attributes.background:
The Hazardous Waste Policy states:  “You must make sure hazardous waste produced or handled by your business in England causes no harm or damage. You have responsibilities known as your ‘duty of care’”

Emissions are currently not part of planning permissions.
attributes.additional_details:
Global Climate Change is proof that carbon-type emissions “are harmful to humans or the environment”.

When proposing new business premises, plans for safe disposal of Hazardous Waste are essential for approval. This should now be a requirement for all emissions (including Nitrous Oxide, Methane) that any new infrastructure will produce. This will help stop further increases in the national emissions at a point where we have recognised the urgent need to drastically lower them. It also encourages embedded corporate responsibility.

attributes.action: Increase funding for more Environmental Wardens and litter/waste initiatives
attributes.background: Increased funding for all local councils to help tackle the growing litter tsunami hitting our public areas and roadsides. More Environmental Wardens to increase public awareness that dropping litter, failing to clean up after their dog and fly-tipping are all illegal and carry on the spot fines.
attributes.additional_details:
Climate Change is this week's buzz phrase. Earth Day having passed on 22.04.21 highlighted how much this Government is failing to take responsibility for the increasing waste & litter habits whilst hiding behind austerity measures.

Increased funds for Environmental Wardens & litter initiatives are required to turn around the route causes behind Climate Change. CCTV at fly-tipping hotspots & increasing public awareness of the impact waste has on their planet is crucial.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban political parties from receiving donations from fossil fuel interests
attributes.background: To enable urgent climate change actions and improve transparency in politics, we call for a complete ban on political parties from receiving donations from individuals or companies with vested interests in oil, gas and coal.
attributes.additional_details: These groups have a lot of influence in our politics, where money and powerful lobbying interests can have more sway in formulating party policies than the voter who is supposed to be represented. As such I feel we no longer live in a genuinely representative democracy. Climate change actions are urgently needed but corporate and individual fossil fuel interests have held back needed change. Therefore we demand that all Parties be banned from receiving donations from such interests.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Ban the use of private jets to help climate change
attributes.background: As we are constantly reminded that 'we the people' must change our living habits to produce net zero carbon emissions, let's start by banning private jets from our airspace to help lower the country's pollution.
attributes.additional_details: The people in society that can afford to travel on private jets should set an example by not using private jets to travel or commute. Unfortunately the users of private jets are hypocritical to demand change but dont act. Ban all private jets from british airspace. 50 people on 1 plane not 50 people on 50 planes.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Reduce the national speed limit to 60 MPH on motorways and dual carriageways
attributes.background: Road transport is a major contributor to CO2 emissions and poor air quality; these are critical issues which contribute massively to climate change. The longer we leave reducing these emissions the more painful remedial measures will have to be, both in cost and impact on daily life.
attributes.additional_details:
The Government should immediately reduce the national speed limit to 60 MPH on motorways and dual carriageways for all vehicles. This modest reduction could make a worthwhile cut in CO2 emissions with the added benefit of reducing collisions and the stress of driving at relatively low cost. 
We don’t need to wait for any recommendations to come from the Glasgow COP26. We can do our bit now to avoid a climate emergency. Remind the Government that our planet needs urgent help now!

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Implement in full the recommendations made by the UK Committee on Climate Change
attributes.background: To create a “Climate and Ecological Emergency Department”, with ring-fenced funding, that will oversee the work required to ensure that the Government implements the recommendations made by the UK Committee on Climate Change.
attributes.additional_details: The report from the UK Committee on Climate Change in 2019 revealed the government had only implemented in full one of the twenty-five recommendations the Committee had made. To overcome this block, there needs to be a fully funded department responsible for ensuring that the annual recommendations are implemented and to estimate the cost. A Climate tax also needs to be introduced to fund this.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban domestic flights on routes that could be travelled by train in under 3 hours
attributes.background: Follow France's example to ban domestic flights in the UK on routes that could be travelled by train in 3 hours or less.
attributes.additional_details:
To reduce the emissions caused by air travel to reduce environmental impact. Many short flights are unnecessary and with the exceptional railway network in the UK there is no reason why people should not take the train instead of flying.

In the current 2019-2021 environmental bill there is no mention of reducing flights or even of off setting carbon emissions caused by aviation. This is not good enough and this ban would be a simple way to reduce the impact of the UK to climate change.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Set minimum energy efficiency standards for retail fridges
attributes.background:
Supermarket refrigeration uses 1% of the UK's energy.
Inefficient fridge design leads to:
1) wasted energy
2) food spoilage and waste as temperature varies across the cabinet
3) increased plastic packaging to protect food that is kept at the wrong temperature
attributes.additional_details:
The world is under threat from the effects of global warming.

Legislating for improved fridge efficiency should help reduce our carbon footprint and prevent climate change.

Fridge doors may be useful, but can cause problems with hygiene (particularly since the covid-19 pandemic) and for people with mobility issues. Therefore the aim should be improving efficiency whilst maintaining the open design if possible.

I propose legislating for a target of 50% improvement in energy efficiency over the next 10 years.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Allow all British Army servicemen to wear a beard
attributes.background: The Royal navy has allowed men to wear trimmed beards for years, the RAF has recently brought in amendments to allow servicemen to grow beards.
attributes.additional_details:
With recruitment and retention at an all time low this small change could boost morale and be a demonstration that the army does listen to its soldiers.
 
It may be in the Government’s interest for recruitment and retention in particular in these current times.
 
It should also make the Army feel more inclusive of current climate and fashion trends.

departments.name: Ministry of Defence

attributes.action: Place large environmental taxes on the use of private jets
attributes.background: Hefty environmental taxes should be placed on those who decide to pollute the environment for no good reason but too show off wealth, power and status. These extra taxes can then be used to inject cash into new technologies and infrastructures to reach our target of being carbon neutral by 2050
attributes.additional_details: These small steps going to have to be implemented quickly and effectively to have any chance of combatting climate change and it consequences.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Hold a referendum on the UK meeting net zero much earlier than 2050.
attributes.background: The rising price of fossil fuels is placing an unaffordable burden on the British people. Our reliance on imports of foreign fossil fuels also weakens our national security. We need to ditch our expensive and dangerous reliance on oil, coal and gas far quicker than is currently planned.
attributes.additional_details: The huge rise in energy bills is caused by increasingly expensive fossil fuels. These are responsible for 85% of the rise in bills in the UK according to energy think tank Ember. Green energy saves people money, ends our reliance on gas and oil imported from Britain's enemies and helps limit the flooding and extreme weather caused by climate change and which damages so many communities in Britain. We need to move much faster to achieve these benefits than 2050.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Require all new buildings to have rainwater storage for flushing toilets
attributes.background: This simple and relatively cheap measure would use a wasted resource and reduce water charges. It would reduce the amount of rainwater going directly into foul drainage, a major cause of untreated discharge of sewage into rivers and the sea. My system used recycled containers and cost about £150.
attributes.additional_details:
This measure could contribute to the national effort to combat climate change & could eventually have a small effect on flood reduction.
 
If extended, perhaps by Government grants, to include existing properties, the benefits to climate change & flood reduction could be very worthwhile.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Rewild 1/3 of UK waters and 1/3 of UK land
attributes.background: The Government should commit to rewilding 1/3 of our national waters and 1/3 of the UKs land. These reserves would be protected from any fishing, forestry and any industry.
attributes.additional_details: We have not yet halted biodiversity and habitat loss. The country and our waters must become sustainable, the sooner we reach this balance the stronger our country will be and the less suffering and global destruction will occur. We could be a world leader on biodiversity and fighting climate change.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban plastic bags in supermarkets, and other retail shops.
attributes.background: I would like the government to ban plastic bags in all supermarkets, takeaway restaurants, and other shops. I have found that having reusable plastic bags isn’t enough because people still throw them out. And small businesses still use them. The government must enforce this because businesses won’t.
attributes.additional_details: Climate change is real, there is lots of evidence on that. If we want to help stop climate change we MUST stop it quickly. Climate change is also something I am very passionate about, because this is about saving our planet, our lives. Plastic bags make up a huge amount of waste which is contributing to the death of our planet, our home. THE only one we have. Waiting for shops to make this change is not enough. The government must take action.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Seek binding agreement at COP26 to make it mandatory to teach climate change.
attributes.background: Earth is trapping unprecedented amounts of heat evidenced by NASA reports, the Global warming index Oxford University and the draft UN report. Unfortunately the world population is less well aware and educated about the long term consequences of climate change that outweigh the Covid pandemic.
attributes.additional_details: The UK government has a great opportunity at COP26 to seek a binding agreement for individual countries within their different educational systems to make climate change a mandatory curriculum course to inspire innovation and awareness at tertiary and school institutions. There is a cost for lack of knowledge and a opportunity for the economics of climate change.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Climate Change. Promote 50mph speed limit on all but electric vehicles/ coaches.
attributes.background: Mount a lengthy advertising and information campaign to encourage drivers into travelling more slowly (50mph suggested). As a final resort, this could become legislation. Exempting electric vehicles and coaches would encourage the use of these forms of transport.
attributes.additional_details:
Transport is the largest source of man made CO2 emissions. Involving the public in a move to reduce these by encouraging slower driving and slower drivers could have several effects-
1 Make slower driving the socially acceptable norm.
2 Reduce CO2 emissons by-
a. reducing fuel usage
b. reducing the interest in longer distance travel, 
c. encouraging a move to electric vehicles,
d. encouraging coach travel with its lower per capita fuel consumption.

departments.name: Department for International Trade

attributes.action: Reverse the decision to merge DFID with the FCO
attributes.background: On 16 June PM Boris Johnson announced his plans to merge the Department for International Development (DFID) with the Foreign & Commonwealth Office (FCO). The goal of DFID is and always has been to promote equality and sustainable development, and to eliminate world poverty. It should remain intact.
attributes.additional_details: DFID is one of the best performing departments in Government and a soft power asset for Britain. It works to save lives, fight climate change, and achieve gender equality. To lead the global fight against poverty and corruption, we must continue to provide the world's most vulnerable with essential support. Plus, merging the two departments will cost millions. We are in the midst of a global pandemic that should be taking priority. This is not the time to dissolve a vital Government Department.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Require specified levels of hedge planting for all new developments
attributes.background: Please set statutory requirements for every building erected and green/brown site built on, or cemented that sufficient hedging is planted for wildlife.
attributes.additional_details:
Developers are tearing down our environment at a great rate of knots.
Please write into constitutional law that all builders and developers MUST combat climate change by hedge (and/or) tree planting. They are quite happy to dodge loopholes on building local amenities i.e. schools by subcontracting, many have no social conscience. If you could please put in law that for every acre they decimate they must replant a portion of greenery to protect humans and wildlife from weathering and erosion, you do us all a favour. No trees, high winds. No food chain, issues.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Introduce a carbon tax
attributes.background: The government should introduce a tax on all commodities and activities that emit carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. For example, there should be a tax on flying by plane etc.
attributes.additional_details: The government should do this to help the fight against climate change. As the price of carbon-emitting activities increase, the consumption of such products should decrease, which should cause more people to shift to renewable energy. This could greatly reduce the carbon footprint of the UK.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Create charge for use of non-biodegradable material
attributes.background: Single use plastic, particularly in the food industry, is having a detrimental impact on the environment. Parliament should make a law that requires businesses to charge for these products if customers require single use plastic products (such as plastic straws) made from non-biodegradable material.
attributes.additional_details: In 2015 it was made law in the UK that large retailers could charge 5p for the requirement of plastic bags. Climate change and the impact of single use plastics is a topic which is always on the public agenda for discussion in the UK. We would like to see a progressive approach to the law in this area and therefore we would like to gain support for a charge for all single use plastics.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase required teaching on climate change in the national curriculum
attributes.background: We want the Government to require 33 hours of climate education each school year, woven through all subjects on our national curriculum. This should help people better understand, adapt to and address the impact of climate change, from an early age.
attributes.additional_details:
The Peoples' Climate Vote found that 64% of people believe we are in a climate emergency. More action is needed. Part of the UN's Sustainable Development Goal for education is that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development.
 
We are making progress by introducing a Natural History GCSE, however providing a solid grounding in environmental awareness from age 4-18 is essential to educate and empower young people to take effective action. We must invest in further climate education to help meet the UKs net zero goals.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Place large environmental taxes on the use of private jets
attributes.background: Hefty environmental taxes should be placed on those who decide to pollute the environment for no good reason but too show off wealth, power and status. These extra taxes can then be used to inject cash into new technologies and infrastructures to reach our target of being carbon neutral by 2050
attributes.additional_details: These small steps going to have to be implemented quickly and effectively to have any chance of combatting climate change and it consequences.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Preserve diverse and mature woodlands in view of climate change.
attributes.background: To review policies concerning 'woodland management', in particular the PAWs restoration document in view of  the effects of climate change.
attributes.additional_details: The large scale removal of mature native and established none-native tree species from our mixed woodlands is not sustainable.  Woodland regeneration is slow and uncertain. Mature trees including conifer varieties have become established and play a vital role in the formation of twenty first century woodlands. I would ask the government to further protect existing woodlands in all their diversity for the benefit of people and wildlife.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Make it a legal requirement that all new homes have solar energy installed.
attributes.background: I would like the government to introduce a bill to legally bind the construction companies building new houses and flats in the UK , to include with the construction solar panels in the roof. This would help on home running costs and assist in our climate policy pledge on carbon emissions.
attributes.additional_details:
I want the Government to do this as solar panels installed within new homes would be far cheaper than retro fitting after construction. Plus they could be included into the building at the design stage. The homes should be designed with roof direction and slope to maximise energy production.

The bill would be worded with a minimum level of panels per size of home. 

This bill would show that the Government is acting on energy prices.
The Bill would also show we are working towards reducing our carbon emissions and progressing towards our climate change objectives.

It would also show that new homes could be built with energy affordability in mind .

It would  also help in marketing new homes with energy performance  certificates at better levels.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Set a target for 70% of UK energy to be renewable by 2030
attributes.background: We would like the Government to seek to reduce carbon emissions by considerable amounts by setting a target to increase the UK's renewable energy generation to account for 70% of all energy. By achieving this we hope to reduce pollution and the amount of carbon emissions from the UK.
attributes.additional_details: We would like to stop climate change progressing further than it's currently estimated to rise to in order to save our planet. Fossil fuels are one of the biggest contributors to climate change. Not only that but we rely on fossil fuels to complete everyday tasks. However, fossil fuels will eventually run out so we need a suitable solution to fall back on. To save ourselves and our planet we must make more use of renewable energy sources such as hydro-electric, solar and wind energy.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: End UK subsidies to the fishing industry
attributes.background:
Biodiversity is crucial in the fight against climate change. The ocean and marine life is critical in both the removal carbon dioxide and the production of oxygen.

Subsidies were created to maintain food supply, this is no longer required. Fishing damages biodiversity and now food shortages
attributes.additional_details: No longer subsidise the fishing industry and repurpose monies to entities that looking to combat climate change and promote biodiversity.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Make public transport free like it is in Luxembourg
attributes.background: The Luxembourg government has made all public transport free to reduce air pollution, congestion and greenhouse gases. It also improves the health of the general public. It's paid for out of taxes. We should too or at least make it heavily subsidized like the buses used to be in Sheffield.
attributes.additional_details: Up until the early 1980s the buses in Sheffield were heavily subsidized to such an extent that public transport was virtually free. Very few bus fares were more than 10p. Given the failure of the COP 26 Climate change conference to deliver anything of substance we should, as a G7 country, lead by example.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban the production of virgin (new) plastics immediately
attributes.background: The Government needs to implement action to tackle plastic waste. Plastics are ending up in the bellies of sea animals and birds and ending up in our (Human) food cycle. By banning the production of new plastics, this should force manufacturers to use more environmentally friendly materials.
attributes.additional_details: The Government needs to implement action to stop the production of new virgin plastics and force the use of environmentally friendly materials already in circulation, to help the fight against climate change.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Add a 'sustainability charge' on meat products to cover their environmental cost
attributes.background: Food production accounts for one-quarter of the world’s greenhouse gas emissions and takes up half of the planet’s habitable surface. The mass of animals raised for slaughter on Earth now outweighs wildlife by a factor of 15-to-1. One kilogram of beef needs about 15 thousand litres of water.
attributes.additional_details: By adding a 'sustainability charge' to meat products, this will encourage more conscious meat consumption. With this money going towards tackling climate change and renewable energy resources.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Work internationally to make solar energy the primary energy source
attributes.background:
We believe Climate Change is greatest threat to humanity. An April 2020 Opinion Poll reported 48% of respondents wanted a radical urgent response to it.
 
The UK Government should work with the Commonwealth and members of APEC to make solar energy the world’s primary energy source.
attributes.additional_details:
• The Sun provides 10,000 times more energy than world uses, and is one of the cleanest & most reliable energy sources.
• 43,000 sq miles of solar panels could supply all of the world’s current energy needs.
• Solar panels installed over 3 main areas of Australia/USA/Africa could replace 85% of all fossil fuels by 2030
• We call on the Government to start this urgent action in a joint project with the 18 major CHOGM/APEC members.

Find out more: http://chatasign.com/index.php?action=proposal

departments.name: Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office

attributes.action: Form an emergency cross-party Government to handle the climate emergency
attributes.background: We need an emergency cross-party government to be formed to see us through the ongoing Climate and Ecological Emergency. We recommend that the emergency government use the Citizens Assembly negotiating method to make the difficult decisions that will be required.
attributes.additional_details: Some of the changes in behaviour arising from the COVID-19 emergency could, if continued, mitigate the climate crisis. For example, reduced air and cruise travel, working from home where possible, reduced consumption, community-based leisure pursuits and mutual support. We need a smooth transition to a new approach that involves a reduced carbon-footprint which will mitigate the imminent danger of climate breakdown and make the UK a role model for COP26.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Change the Energy Profits Levy (EPL) to help UK households and the climate.
attributes.background: The new investment allowance of 91p (for every £1 spent by the oil and gas sector e.g. companies such as BP and Shell) should apply solely to investment in renewable energy projects. The investment allowance for investing in oil and gas extraction should be reduced to 25p for every £1 spent.
attributes.additional_details: The energy sector can make 91p tax saving for every £1 spent on oil and gas extraction in the UK. This was originally 46p. The new tax saving doesn't apply to renewable energy projects. The UK Government expects £5 billion in tax revenue from the EPL. The 5 biggest oil companies shared profits of nearly $100bn in 1st 6 months of 2022. People need help this winter to afford fuel and food. The economy will need further support. £5 billion additional tax revenue from the current EPL isn't enough.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Fund the planting of wildflowers along all public green spaces
attributes.background: We would like the Government pledge funding to plant a 1-meter wide strip of wildflowers along the length of every public green space (i.e. playing fields, grass verges etc). Councils would be allocated a grant to achieve this target. The target would be set by the Government.
attributes.additional_details:
The data shows the UK has experienced extinctions and declines in abundance, biomass and distribution of insects. Declines in abundance or distribution have been seen in bees and hoverflies, butterflies and moths, beetles, and freshwater insects. There are a variety of drivers behind insect decline, such as habitat loss, chemical use and climate change, and their impacts differ across habitat, species and time.
 
Source: UK Insect Decline and Extinctions, UK Parliament POST https://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/POST-PN-0619/POST-PN-0619.pdf

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Fund free solar panels for all homes
attributes.background: The Government should fund the installation of solar panels for all existing homes and require solar panels to be installed on all new-build homes within 4 years.
attributes.additional_details:
This would significantly contribute to phasing out the use of fossil fuels and allow the UK to take a global lead in fighting climate change.
 
Combating climate change takes steps, and converting our energy uses and harnessing the best natural renewable energy is one of them.
We are already on our way to switching to electric vehicles, we are opening our eyes to the effect we have on the planet.
Let’s live in a clean, renewable country and take a global lead in combating climate change immediately.
We need to act decisively if we want to preserve our way of life, and to protect the animals that are innocent in all of this.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Introduce a National Reforestation Scheme
attributes.background: Start a permanent reforestation scheme of planting locally appropriate tree species across the UK in all public owned spaces & incentivise planting on private land. Establish a panel of experts to recommend operational measures. Nominate a Gov't department to design and implement the scheme.
attributes.additional_details: Long term local and global  benefit of large scale diverse tree planting include: Improvement in quality of life for all, climate change prevention, creation of habitats for all wildlife, better air quality, prevention of flooding, a healthier population, prevention of loss of habitats and soil erosion and job creation. It is unethical to disregard this as it would be cheap and reasonable to start a scheme that could have a diverse and profound impact for the greater public good.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Withdraw from the Paris agreement related to climate change
attributes.background: The Paris Agreement is a legally binding international treaty on climate change.
attributes.additional_details:
Its goal is to limit global warming to well below 2, preferably to 1.5 degrees Celsius, compared to pre-industrial levels.
 
I am asking the Government to pull out of this agreement.
 
I believe the government has been spending too much money on providing cleaner energy, which is a problem when the national deficit is too high. An example is subsidies to those building wind turbines. I believe this Paris agreement is influencing road taxes for car users as the Government tries to meet its climate goals. Also, businesses may face higher taxes, later on, to pay back the national deficit. I believe that to improve our economy and financial well-being we need to pull out of the Paris agreement.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban drilling for fossil fuels and put more money into using renewable energy.
attributes.background: We see destruction to the environment every day that passes. I believe by banning the drilling on fossil fuels, we can make a difference to what is happening to the Earth right now, alternatively we should use renewable energy and have the government use the technology we have right now.
attributes.additional_details: The banning of drilling for fossil fuels will push more to our goals for the climate, In a few months COP26 will be held in Scotland to discuss the climate crisis; by then it may be more frequent in use meaning more research to improve renewable energy. Thirdly, I believe by doing this other world leaders will follow by example by doing the right thing for the Earth, climate change affects everyone and we need to actually do something longer term rather than short term.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Impose a limit on party donations of £1,000 per individual per party per year
attributes.background:
Impose a limit on donations to political parties to £1000 per person per party per year and restrict party donations to individuals only (no companies or other organisations).
 
If an organisation or individual were to be found breaking this, the funds would be seized by the government.
attributes.additional_details:
There are concerns that Government policy, on issues such as climate change and the escalating energy crisis, is influenced by wealthy individuals and companies that donate to political parties. 
 
Under the system proposed, donations to parties would be limited to individuals, allowing for supporters of a party to still be able to donate but also assuring that the integrity of our democracy is preserved from influence by large donors. This should help ensure that parties serve their voters, and not big donors.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: All infrastructure projects be tested against the Net Zero Emissions 2050 Law
attributes.background: Ensure that all current and future infrastructure projects as part of Budget 2020 and beyond are rigorously tested against the Net Zero Emissions 2050 law. Sustainable and low carbon projects should then be prioritised including renewable energy and mass public transit.
attributes.additional_details:
The evidence that we are in the midst of a global climate emergency is obvious, the science is obvious. But more than that we can see the impact of climate change every day from floods, to bush fires, Greenland and Antarctica ice melting faster than ever, to the decline in biodiversity. This is not a drill, we need real leadership and we need it now. 

This government speaks about the people's priorities and surely the biggest priority for everyone is a planet that is safe to live on.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Get the UK's carbon emissions to net-zero by 2040.
attributes.background: Set a strategy so that carbon emissions can be reduced to net zero by 2030, or by 2040 at the absolute latest as the current target of 2050 is too late
attributes.additional_details: Children are concerned about the state the planet will be in when they are adults and want more to be done now to combat climate change.
